Introduction

Norovirus, a leading cause of acute viral gastroenteritis worldwide, is a highly contagious virus transmitted via the fecal-oral route.  Infection affects people of all ages and is particularly prevalent in closed, crowded environments.  Symptoms include vomiting, watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and fatigue.

Pathogenesis



Norovirus is a small, nonenveloped RNA virus that is transmitted primarily via the fecal-oral route, most often through person-to-person contact or contact with contaminated surfaces.  Infection can also occur through the consumption of contaminated food or water, including items such as raw shellfish, leafy greens, and fresh fruits.  Norovirus is highly contagious and particularly virulent for the following reasons:



  • Low infectious dose:  Only a small number of viral particles are required to cause infection,  which explains why outbreaks are common in closed or crowded environments.
  • Environmental stability:  The virus is resistant to many common disinfectants (except bleach) and can withstand freezing and moderate heating, allowing it to persist on surfaces and in food.
  • Prolonged viral shedding:  Infected individuals may shed viral particles in stool for weeks after symptom resolution, increasing the risk for transmission.


Norovirus infects primarily the small intestine, where it causes mucosal injury that disrupts both absorptive and secretory functions, leading to acute gastroenteritis characterized by vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps.

Risk factors



  • Crowded settings:  Individuals in day care, in long-term care facilities, on cruise ships, in military barracks, and in prisons tend to have an increased risk for norovirus infection.
  • Contaminated food or water.
  • Infants (age <12 months), elderly patients, immunocompromised individuals:  These patients tend to have more severe manifestations and a higher risk for complications (eg, dehydration, prolonged clinical course).

Clinical presentation



Symptoms typically begin 1-2 days after viral exposure and include the abrupt onset of:



  • Nausea and nonbloody, nonbilious vomiting (most prominent symptom).
  • Watery diarrhea without blood or mucus.
  • Abdominal cramping.
  • Low-grade fever, malaise, headache, and myalgia.

Differential diagnosis



  • Bacterial gastroenteritis (eg, Salmonella, Shigella, Escherichia coli):  Typically presents with an acute onset of high fever, abdominal cramping, and diarrhea that contains mucus and/or blood.
  • Rotavirus infection (

  • Giardiasis:  Characterized by foul-smelling, watery diarrhea; bloating; flatulence; and greasy, bulky stool (indicates fat malabsorption).  Symptoms of this protozoal infection may persist for weeks if untreated.
  • Clostridioides difficile infection:  Manifests with profuse, watery diarrhea (with or without blood), abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis.  Prior antibiotic exposure (eg, fluoroquinolones, clindamycin) is the most significant risk factor.
  • Toxin-mediated food poisoning (eg, Bacillus cereus, Staphylococcus aureus):  Causes foodborne gastrointestinal illness via ingestion of preformed toxin.  Rapid onset of vomiting is the predominant symptom and typically begins within 6 hours of eating contaminated food.

Diagnosis



Norovirus infection is typically diagnosed clinically based on a history of abrupt-onset gastroenteritis with a short incubation period and self-limited course, particularly in the context of a known outbreak.  Confirmatory testing (eg, reverse transcriptase PCR [RT-PCR]) may be warranted in outbreak investigations or atypical presentations, such as symptoms lasting longer than 7 days or in immunocompromised patients.

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory evaluation for norovirus is usually not performed and is generally reserved only for select cases but may include:



Stool tests



  • RT-PCR:  Detects norovirus RNA in stool samples.
  • Enzyme immunoassays (EIA):  Detects norovirus antigen in a stool sample but is less sensitive than RT-PCR.  EIA is used mostly for rapid detection in outbreaks.
  • Stool leukocytes and culture:  Used to rule out bacterial pathogens, if clinically indicated (eg, high fever, mucus/bloody stool).  Fecal leukocytes suggest bacterial infection and are not typically seen in norovirus infection.
  • Stool ova and parasite tests:  Used to microscopically discover parasites (eg, Giardia, Entamoeba histolytica, Cryptosporidium) in persistent cases or after travel to an endemic region.


Blood tests



  • Basic metabolic panel:  Used to assess for dehydration, electrolyte abnormalities (eg, hypokalemia), and metabolic acidosis (from bicarbonate stool losses).
  • Complete blood count:  Usually unremarkable but may show slight leukocytosis.

Imaging studies



Imaging is not routinely indicated in the evaluation of viral gastroenteritis.  However, abdominal ultrasonography or CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis may be considered in patients with severe or localized abdominal pain, significant tenderness, high fever, or abdominal distension.  These modalities are particularly used to rule out complications such as paralytic ileus, intussusception, or an alternate diagnosis (eg, appendicitis).

Management



Treatment for norovirus is supportive because the illness is typically self-limited, with symptoms resolving spontaneously within 2 to 3 days.



  • Hydration:  Oral rehydration is recommended for mild to moderate dehydration (eg, normal vital signs, dry mucous membranes).  Intravenous fluids may be necessary for severe dehydration (eg, tachycardia, decreased urine output) or for a patient unable to tolerate oral intake.
  • Antiemetics (eg, ondansetron, prochlorperazine):  These medications are used to control nausea and vomiting.
  • Antidiarrheals:  Antidiarrheal medications are not typically recommended due to a lack of clear benefit and some risk for harm (eg, ileus, lethargy).
  • Bland diet:  Patients should avoid foods high in fat, which can be difficult to digest, and sugars, which may draw fluid into the intestines and exacerbate diarrhea.

Prognosis



Norovirus is typically a self-limited illness with an excellent prognosis.  Although mortality is low, symptoms may be more severe in young children, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals.  Potential complications include severe dehydration, acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalances, chronic diarrhea, malnutrition, and weight loss.

Prevention



Because norovirus is resistant to alcohol-based hand sanitizers and many standard disinfectants, prevention relies on strict hand hygiene with soap and water and thorough cleaning of contaminated surfaces using bleach-based solutions.  To reduce the risk for transmission, food service workers should avoid handling food for at least 48 hours after symptom resolution, and health care personnel should remain off duty for 2 to 3 days after symptoms subside.
